headline: Bank earnings, CPI inflation data, Fed comments: What to Watch
summary: Market Domination Overtime Host Josh Lipton previews several of the biggest stories to come next week, including earnings results reported by the Big Banks, December's Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation data, and a slew of commentary from Federal Reserve officials. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

content.title: Bank earnings, CPI inflation data, Fed comments: What to Watch

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination Overtime.

headline: Review & Preview: Lackluster Jobs, Lively Market
summary: Wall Street cheered a lower unemployment rate, even though the November jobs figure missed expectations.  The Nasdaq Composite rallied 0.8%.  At 4.4%, the unemployment rate still came in below the expected 4.5%, and November’s figure was revised lower to 4.5%.

content.title: Review & Preview: Lackluster Jobs, Lively Market
content.summary: Wall Street cheered a lower unemployment rate, even though the November jobs figure missed expectations.  The Nasdaq Composite rallied 0.8%.  At 4.4%, the unemployment rate still came in below the expected 4.5%, and November’s figure was revised lower to 4.5%.

headline: From SpaceX to Anthropic, 2026 Looks Like a Big Year for IPOs
summary: A pack of large private start-ups hungry for capital look ready to try a newly revived initial-public-offering market. SpaceX could be the largest, but AI companies could dominate the year.

content.title: From SpaceX to Anthropic, 2026 Looks Like a Big Year for IPOs
content.summary: A pack of large private start-ups hungry for capital look ready to try a newly revived initial-public-offering market. SpaceX could be the largest, but AI companies could dominate the year.

headline: I’m a JPMorgan Chase Advisor: 4 Costly Banking Mistakes Putting Your Money at Risk
summary: Avoiding common banking mistakes like weak passwords, paper checks, phishing scams and ignoring free fraud monitoring can protect your money and identity.

headline: Trump’s Call for 10% Credit-Card Cap Aims at Banks’ Crown Jewels
summary: After a week of jarring markets with announcements aimed at making homes more affordable, the president swiveled to another consumer burden: the cost of carrying a credit card balance from one month to the next.  This time, his social-media missive pushed a slew of card issuers led by JPMorgan Chase & Co., Capital One Financial Corp. and Citigroup Inc. into the crosshairs.  Card interest rates — hovering above 20% in recent years — have become a target of lawmakers on both sides of the aisle, with bills popping up and meeting stiff resistance from the industry.

headline: How Shifting Analyst Targets Are Rewriting The Story For London Stock Exchange Group (LSE:LSEG)
summary: London Stock Exchange Group has seen its central fair value estimate reaffirmed at £122.84 per share, even as the underlying assumptions behind that figure have been fine tuned. These adjustments reflect how recent Street research is weighing upbeat and cautious views on the company into a single, updated target. Read on to see how you can keep on top of this evolving narrative so you are not caught off guard as opinions and fair value estimates shift over time. Stay updated as the Fair Value...

headline: Bank Stocks Brace for Impact After Trump Calls for 10% Cap on Credit-Card Interest Rates
summary: President Donald Trump on Friday called for credit-card companies to cap the interest rates they charge customers, as the president leans harder into addressing consumers’ affordability concerns.  “Effective January 20, 2026, I, as President of the United States, am calling for a one year cap on Credit Card Interest Rates of 10%,” he said in a Truth Social post.  It was unclear how the move would be enacted, but credit-card companies may already be bracing for a negative stock reaction if a reduction in rates hits their net interest income.

content.title: Bank Stocks Brace for Impact After Trump Calls for 10% Cap on Credit-Card Interest Rates

It was unclear how the move would be enacted, but credit-card companies may already be bracing for a negative stock reaction if a reduction in rates hits their net interest income.

headline: Why Analysts See The Synthomer (LSE:SYNT) Story Shifting After JPMorgan’s Lower Target
summary: JPMorgan’s decision to trim its Synthomer price target to £1.02 from £1.12, while keeping a Neutral rating, shifts the story around the shares without pushing you toward a clear bullish or bearish camp. The move suggests analysts are taking a more cautious view on what the stock might be worth, even though they still see the business as capable of supporting the new target under updated revenue assumptions. Stay with this article to see how you can keep on top of future changes in this...
